pros: The staff brings their heart to work every day. Since of camaraderie, family we help each other and look out for each other. It felt good working with compassionate and people with great heart always advocating to provide the best care.
cons: ED gets to not give report when transferring patients when they are taking a lot of inexperienced nurses who’s lacking critical thinking and time management, provide them with very short training so no one to hold accountable. They are sending unstable patient to unit with no staff increasing patient acuity. I would never want to be a patient in the ER when I use to work there. The nurses are burned out and tired of the lack of support from management.

review_title: A company that will allow you to gain experience and pursue a career in healthcare.
pros: Ellis will help you gain necessary experience in the healthcare industry and allow for you to meet plenty of people. The hospital has undergone several improvements and office space is spacious and nice. Managers provide flexibility to working hours. The hospital provides some formal training if you need it. Working as a technician or nurse allows you to see many people.
cons: The food in the cafeteria leaves much to be desired. Do not expect to advancing up the ladder quickly, but hard work and putting in added effort can help facilitate a growing career at Ellis. Work can sometimes become boring and be very repetitive especially in administrative support roles (Finance, Statistics, Human Resources, etc.).

pros: As long as you do your job with no mistakes management will leave you alone.
cons:
-Managers have no clue how to effectively run their departments.  Constantly in meetings and can never be reached when you need them. 
-Horrible patient care in almost every office due to being short staffed and employees overworked.
-Use of to many computer system that are not really compatible with one another.
-Billing department has no clue about insurances and how to bill for services accurately. They would rather send out collection notices then correct their mistakes and keep patients in the crossfire.

review_title: Very political environment, senior team interested in saving own careers
pros: Very dedicated employees; trying to do the right things every day although they do not see that same behavior in the leadership
cons: The financial instability has made "job security" nonexistent.  Employees joke about surviving another week of employment, whether management or front line staff.  People are "laid off" monthly and their job elimination is never communicated to staff.  People just disappear.

review_title: You could do worse than to work here, but beware if you're starting out at the Entry Level
pros:
Very affordable medical benefits for a single person, decent pay on par with other hospitals in the area, shift differential a plus, a fair amount of paid time off, probably one of the better places in Schenectady to work.

A definite step up in wages and benefits if you're coming from fast food or retail.

Extremely flexible in hours if you're also going to school.

Once you pass your probation, it's pretty hard to get fired, even if you're being scolded every day(obviously a positive if you're a slacker, but a negative if you're an honest, hard-working employee who has to pick up the slack of others).
cons:
***To be fair, many of these issues are probably present in many others hospitals and businesses also.

The threat of job cuts and layoffs are always abundant in the lower wage positions that are usually working VERY short as it is.

Hard work is always expected but rarely recognized, but slack off even a little and management will be ready to pick you apart like vultures on a carcass.

The so-called "annual" raise of 3% is sometimes cut down to 2% or 2.5%, and pushed back because the hospital will say they can't afford it, so employees have to wait 15-18 months just for the hope of getting a 0.20- 0.30 cent raise. Meanwhile upper management and physicians still get their (much larger) raises, fancy parties, and company trips.

You can work up to 40+ hours as a "Part Time B" employee, and receive absolutely no benefits whatsoever for it, and your months/years of service as a PTB will NOT count if you eventually move up to PTA or FT. On paper, you will be the same as a new employee, even though you may have been there for quite some time.

If you're lucky enough(or unlucky enough, if it's mandated and you've already got plans that have to be canceled at the absolute last minute) to land some overtime at a moment's notice due to last minute staffing issues, you may be forced to take an extra day off to offset the costs, leaving very little incentives for doing extra to help out your department. But if it isn't mandated and you say no, you're suddenly not a "team player."

Secretaries sometimes have to cover multiple departments/ floors by themselves.

pros:
-decent benefits and pay
-tuition assistance program (based on first-come/first-serve)
-steady schedule
cons:
-management plays musical chairs
-reputation and profit come well before employee satisfaction
